Award.AwardTitle: The Evolution of Cranial Forms in Anguilliform Fishes: Does Extreme Biting Promote or Constrain Morphological Diversity?
Award.AbstractNarration: The diversification of novel body forms and behavior patterns is of central interest in biology. One factor that may guide or constrain diversity in organismal design is the correlation of traits: individual trait diversity may be limited by their associations with other traits. Alternatively, a large change in one character or in a suite of functionally related traits may have far-reaching consequences on the integration of complex systems, greatly affecting the outcome of system design and behavior. Fish skulls are highly complex musculoskeletal systems that are used for critical survival behaviors such as prey capture, prey transport (swallowing), and respiration. Our knowledge of skull design in teleost fishes is derived almost entirely from studies of suction feeding, the dominant mode of prey capture, prey transport, and respiration for the majority of fishes. However, biting is an alternative prey capture behavior that has evolved across many fish groups and the evolutionary dynamics of morphological and behavioral evolution in biting lineages is poorly understood. This study will test the idea that the evolution of biting has promoted diversification in behavior and morphology in one of the most prominent groups of biting fishes: eels and their allies. Fishes that bite their prey rather than use suction, have modified their jaws in diverse ways. In some cases, jaw modification has had cascading effects on the transport and respiratory complex for some of these fish species that capture their prey by biting. For example, moray eels, a species rich group belonging to a larger group of fishes known as the anguilliforms, or true eels, do not rely on suction for capturing or swallowing their prey. Morays capture their prey by sinking their teeth into them. Once the prey is captured, morays protract their pharyngeal jaws, a second set of jaws in their throat, into their mouths to grab the prey item and transport the prey into their esophagus. This swallowing behavior is unlike any other fish transport behavior and presents the first alternative method for transporting prey without the use of suction in the aquatic environment. This novelty in moray transport behavior provides an opportunity to examine how functional innovations in integrated systems arise. This study will be the first comparative analysis on the functional implications of biting on teleost skull diversity. This work will also improve our understanding of eel relationships and will integrate fossil information with newly collected genetic data to produce the first time tree for the group. With this tree we propose to identify broad patterns of trait associations and trait modularity in the skull of eels to illustrate how a change in the oral jaws has had cascading effects on systems used for prey transport, and respiration. The principal investigator is a first time investigator who is committed to recruiting and encouraging young scientists, especially women. The collective efforts of this grant will provide training for graduate students and undergraduates in a variety of anatomical techniques, while also providing opportunities for these developing scientists to attend scientific meetings.

POR.DRECONTENT: This research contributes towards our understanding the factors that promote or constrain the diversity of biological forms, a central problem in evolutionary biology. Organisms are comprised of structural elements that interact through shared genes, developmental pathways and biological functions. These factors integrate or combine the many parts of organisms into suites of structures, known as modules.  Modules exhibit strong covariation through ontogeny within individuals, as well as among individuals within populations. Strong relationships between structures that comprise these modules can be a potent constraining factor during evolution by facilitating stability within modules as species diverge.  Most important to this research project is to understand how the degree to which morphological traits work together to perform biological functions can affect organismal design. The dependence of traits on each other may influence their capacity to produce different varieties. Strong functional integration is thought to constrain morphological diversity because the performance consequences of variation in any single trait will depend on the states of other traits. As behavior is an emergent property resulting from the sum of an organism’s parts, one can imagine how the appearance of a new behavior pattern may dramatically alter the way structures interact and therefore, release the constraints of functional dependence. We use the evolution of a novel feeding behavior in the aquatic environment and the skulls of bony fish to demonstrate our example. Specifically, we designed a project where we measured over 23 elements of the skull for 62 species of fishes, the majority of which belonged to a group known as “the true eels” (Anguilliformes). Unlike the vast majority of bony fishes, the true eels are primarily biters. However, within this very large eel group that captures their prey by biting, we also observe suction feeding eels that have evolved independently multiple times. Suction feeding is the most common method of prey capture in the aquatic environment. Successful suction feeding requires a very rapid increase in mouth cavity volume to generate water flow strong enough to carry prey into the mouth. The skull module movements involved in mouth expansion are highly coordinated and repeatable within individual suction feeders and strongly conserved across a hugely diverse array of aquatic feeding species, such as sharks and salamanders. There is a temporal progression of movement across different parts of the skull in suction feeding fishes which results in an anterior-to-posterior wave of mouth expansion that is mechanically essential for maintaining a unidirectional flow of water into the mouth while the mouth is open. Moreover, speed of expansion is strongly and positively related to the velocity and acceleration of the suction-induced water flow and to the hydrodynamic forces exerted on prey. Coordination of modules in the skull is therefore critical to the success of prey capture by suction, and this feeding mode requires tight functional integration of 3 major components of the fish skull which we term modules. These modules are better known as the oral jaws (mouth), the hyoid (underside of the head), and the opercular series (lateral sides of the head). We hypothesized that biting is a novel mode of aquatic prey capture that has the potential to disrupt the evolutionary integration of these skull modules. With the help of Michael E. Alfaro’s lab at UCLA, we constructed the first time-calibrated phylogenetic tree hypothesizing the evolutionary relationships for the true eels. This tree was critical for performing our comparative analyses and reaching our conclusions.
